object.name: theexplainer
object.title: Prior understanding of Equilibrium.
object.text:
In this simulation you will explore the concept of myoglobin oxygen complex formation and equilibrium.

To help you monitor your learning please write a definition for equilibrium on the survey provided. You will be given a chance to update your definition at the end.


When you are ready to continue click "Next."

object.name: theexplainer
object.title: Equilibrium state determined by protein and ligand concentrations.
object.text:
Myoglobin binds oxygen to form a myoglobin-oxygen complex within muscle fibers. This simulation will demonstrate the equilibrium of this complex formation. In the simulation you will see only a few myoglobin molecules. This represents a tiny fraction of the amount that would be in muscle fibers.
The reaction diagram to the right represents the relationship between unbound myoglobin M and free oxygen O establishing an equilibrium with a myoglobin-oxygen MO complex. Note that between the free and bound molecules there is a set of half arrows that represent that the binding is reversible. The simulation will show you the reversibility of binding.
Click "Next" to continue.

object.name: theexplainer
object.title: Equilibrium state determined by protein and ligand concentrations.
object.text:
In the simulation window you will explore how the concentration of O drives the formation of MO complex.
You will start with 4 M molecules (the red balls) and with 15 O molecules (the yellow balls). The white spot on M indicated the binding site for O. The bound MO complexes are represented by the purple ball bound to the red ball.After pressing start watch the simulation window to see how the oxygen binds with the myoglobin and then releases after some time period.

Click "Start" to begin the simulation.

object.name: theexplainer
object.title: Simulation
object.text:
When the protein binds with the ligand, it stays bound for some constant period of time and then releases. The amount of time they stay bound defines the binding affinity for this particular pair.
The binding and release of the ligand is reversible binding.

Watch the action for a short period and then click "Continue."

object.name: theexplainer
object.title: Simulation
object.text: Here the value boxes are displaying the numbers of M, O, and MO at a moment in time.

object.name: theexplainer
object.title: Simulation Runs
object.text: The Chart Recorder at the bottom is recording the instantaneous number of MO.

object.name: theexplainer
object.title: Simulation Runs
object.text:
The Graph at the bottom right is recording the average number of MO complexes being formed over time.
Remember this is a representation of a limited set of molecules. In a normal biological system a large number of molecules would be involved.

object.name: theexplainer
object.title: Starting over
object.text:
Let's start over.



Click "Continue" to watch it all together.

object.name: theexplainer
object.title: Explanation of action
object.text:
Count the number of myoglobin-oxygen complexes. Compare that number to the number in the box under MO and the last point of the chart recorder. The chart recorder is plotting the instantaneous number of complexes. In the graph the horizontal (x) axis is time and the vertical (y) axis represents the average number of MO complexes. The chart recorder is plotting the instantaneous number of MO complexes while the graph is plotting the average number of complexes per unit time. You will see that the instantaneous number of the complexes is very dynamic where as the time average is much smoother.

Watch as the simulation reaches equilibrium. When you are ready, click "Continue" to continue the simulation.

object.name: theexplainer
object.title: MO complex formation is a dynamic equilibrium.
object.text:
When the simulation first starts it takes time for the ligand to diffuse. During this time there is a rapid increase in the amount of MO complex formed as you can see in the time averaged graph. After the ligand is randomly distributed, the average number of MO complexes formed levels off.

This represents the equilibrium state.

You should have also noticed that the myoglobin does not bind oxygen indefinitely. Instead, the myoglobin releases the oxygen after a fixed period of time,so that from one instant to the next, the exact number of MO complexes is not the same. Over time, the number of complexes reaches an average number as seen in the graph.
Furthermore, within that average time an individual M can be found in both the bound and unbound state. This equilibrium condition remains the same although the state of individual reactants will vary. At equilibrium some MO complexes come apart and others form.

At equilibrium the state of individual reactants is dynamic.

object.name: theexplainer
object.title: Summary
object.text:
In this simulation there were small numbers of O and the equilibrium value is fairly variable. How would you expect the system to react if it started with more ligand molecules? You will explore this in the following simulation.


When you are ready to continue click "Next."

object.name: theexplainer
object.title: System behavior with larger amounts of O
object.text:
In this simulation there will be 4 M molecules. In the text box below O choose a value of O in the range of 15 to 60. When the system is at equilibrium click the "System at Equilibrium" button. Watch the value of MO in the reaction diagram and the time average of the number of MO complexes. This curve will be plotted along with the curve from the previous simulation.
Click the 'Start' button to begin the simulation.

object.name: theexplainer
object.title: Detecting Equilibrium.
object.text:
Watch the animation paying attention to the number bound and unbound myoglobin molecules. Observe the number of MO in the chart recorder and the graph of the amount of MO over time.

When the system is at equilibrium

click "System at Equilibrium."

object.name: theexplainer
object.title: MO complex formation is dynamic.
object.text:
In this simulation you used a higher number of O molecules. Compare the two curves on the graph. The line representing the average number of MO molecules is much smoother than the previous run. In the first simulation, where there were only 15 oxygen molecules, more myoglobin molecules were found in the unbound state on average. As the number of oxygen molecules increases, the frequency of contact between the myoglobin and oxygen increases and therefore, more of the myoglobin is in the bound state on average. Again, the complex exists as a reversible, dynamic binding complex. Over time, each myoglobin will complex with multiple oxygen molecules, even though the aparent number of complexed myoglobins remains unchanged.
Reversability of the complex is important. In a muscle fiber at rest, myoglobin is in an oxygen saturating environment. This is represented in the second simulation where the myoglobin spends most of the time in complex form. During extreme exercise the muscle fiber becomes oxygen deprived. As myoglobin-oxygen complexes fall apart the recently freed oxygen can be diverted to metabolism. If the binding were not reversible then myoglobin would not release oxygen to oxygen starved muscle fibers.
Reversible binding and equilibrium between free molecules and the complex form is a common theme in biological systems. You will find it in signal transduction across membranes such as neurotransmission and hormone binding and in transport molecules such as myoglobin and hemoglobin.
Click "Done" to conclude the simulation.
